conversation.content: Good morning. I'm calling about a tuition reimbursement issue affecting several staff members in our academic advising department.

Good morning, and thank you for reaching out. I'd be happy to help resolve this issue for your department. May I have your employee ID and the department code so I can access the relevant reimbursement records?
My employee ID is 447892 and we're in Academic Affairs, department code AA-2150.

Perfect, thank you. I have your profile here showing you as Senior Academic Advisor with authorization for departmental reimbursement submissions. Your current fiscal year allocation is $45,000 with $31,750 already processed. What specific issue are you experiencing with the reimbursements?
Three staff members submitted their fall semester reimbursements six weeks ago, but they're still showing as pending in the system.

I understand your concern about the delay. Let me pull up those pending submissions to investigate. Can you provide the submission reference numbers or the employees' names so I can locate them quickly?
The employees are Sarah Chen, Michael Torres, and Jennifer Park. They all submitted on September 15th for courses at State University.

I've located all three submissions in our system. Sarah Chen's request REQ-9847-SC for $2,400, Michael Torres REQ-9848-MT for $2,100, and Jennifer Park REQ-9849-JP for $2,550. They appear to be held up in verification status code VER-04, which indicates missing documentation.
That's strange. We attached all transcripts and payment receipts to each submission. What documentation is the system indicating as missing?

According to the notes here, the verification team flagged these on September 28th requesting form EDU-712A, which is the supervisor's pre-approval form that should have been filed before course enrollment. The notification was sent to the general department email address AA2150@company.com.
I see the problem now. We switched to the new approval process but weren't aware that retroactive approvals weren't acceptable anymore.

I understand the confusion during the transition. The new policy effective September 1st does require pre-approval, but I can see these courses started August 28th, placing them in a grey area. Let me escalate this to our exceptions team with case number EXC-10847-AA for special consideration.
That would be extremely helpful. These employees completed their courses successfully and are counting on this reimbursement as promised.

Absolutely, I completely understand. I've submitted the exception request with priority status and attached a note about the policy transition timing. The exceptions team typically reviews these within 48 to 72 hours, and they'll send their decision directly to you at your registered email address.
What's the likelihood of approval given the circumstances? Should I prepare the staff for possible denial?

Based on similar cases I've seen, the approval rate for transition period exceptions is approximately 85%, especially when the courses began before the policy change. I've also noted that all three employees achieved grades of B or higher, which strengthens the case. Your department's perfect reimbursement history over the past five years is another positive factor.
That's reassuring. Is there anything else I need to provide to support their case?

I'd recommend submitting a brief department memo explaining the situation, which you can attach to case EXC-10847-AA through your portal. Also, please ensure the employees retain all original receipts, as we may need to verify amounts if approved. The maximum reimbursable amount per employee this semester is $3,000, so all three requests fall within guidelines.
I'll draft that memo immediately and upload it today. Will the employees be notified directly once a decision is made?

Yes, once approved, each employee will receive an email confirmation with their payment reference number and timeline. The funds typically process within 5 to 7 business days after approval, depositing directly to their registered accounts. I've also set a flag in your department profile to receive the new policy guide Version 3.2, which will be sent to you by end of business today.

scenario: academic advisor, patient and systematic about explaining a tuition reimbursement problem
